hints.content:
# Introduction

Many shapes have corners. We call a corner a *right angle* if we can fit a little square *perfectly* inside it.

###Consider the trapezoid
 
> ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/90f23a3aba258e90720940a61ea5c1982754fda1)

Let's draw a square in each corner.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/136163e8a5d7586a09b1cd265cdbe5afc136b8b6)


In which corners did the little square fit *perfectly*?

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f8081758208a0824fab2ae3e0aa5470ed9d0053e)

The trapezoid has $2$ right angles.

# Practice

### First, let's study some more examples.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/12f735ca5089f47b03fc19acd7dd246e476de826) ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/43754d1da887445ee14d06000f6f991356a28d21)  ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e6daf280cd5210510960e044f3c18f972b17b144)

### Now, try it yourself.

[[☃ graded-group 2]]

[[☃ graded-group 3]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cef917c266353c6f465c42c0e14a86f863cb8932)   

The pentagon has $2$ right angles.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d04059327df69e4b6ad2bbc17e44c6a60e6c29c1)

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/533c0231ebeb5458a1f5740a424c0503a3d707cc)

Squares fit perfectly in $2$ of the corners, so there are $2$ right angles.

hints.content:
#Quadrilaterals

A quadrilateral is a polygon with $4$ sides.

### Study some  examples

Here are some examples of quadrilaterals:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/11bc2db88076b90f62058e29de0e5f3d921fbb43)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0255558884f12b91e9e253d7a829f5ffcd9fb224)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2626bde85235b21f3117035929bc5e7a0ed8e9fb)

###Try it yourself

[[☃ graded-group 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The following shapes are quadrilaterals because they are polygons with $4$ sides:  
*Remember: Polygons must be closed figures.*

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/63e1a7c9caac702bfd841c730d82bb3bf6854272)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/dabc322de559c84a60ac5d10da5b7c7790978a0d)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/bfb29de4d2e03811f668e83a9ac608cb21298003)

options.content:
**Which of the following shapes are quadrilaterals?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

# Rectangles

What makes a shape a rectangle?

* **$4$ right angles**
* $4$ sides (because it's a quadrilateral)

### Study some examples

Here are some examples of rectangles:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a3286d4fdfafd9b0c0fade3cae60f72aba7f5cdc)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/52601123094edf46a2f306ec224d6b0a1d993865)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1a6dd5df208c862772d7e0515cebbbdd3943f258)

### Try it yourself

[[☃ graded-group 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The following shapes are rectangles because they are quadrilaterals with $4$ right angles:  
*Remember: Quadrilaterals must have $4$ sides.*

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/069f98272a0ffd87d781d7ffc9657c497c16e235)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7e6a1563c875da63594929f7cac3fcfcb9350701)

options.content:
**Which of the following shapes are rectangles?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
### Challenge problem

Let's consider one more shape:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/27d7693f5ac5ea41df1c773cd3f396a3eb26bc81)

[[☃ graded-group 1]]

[[☃ graded-group 2]]

[[☃ graded-group 3]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
That's right!  

A rectangle is a $\blueD{\text{quadrilateral}}$ with $\greenD{\text{4 right angles}}$.

Squares are $\blueD{\text{quadrilaterals}}$.  Squares have $\greenD{\text{4 right angles}}$.

So, squares are rectangles!

options.content:
**Does the shape have $4$ right angles?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

**So, is the shape a rectangle?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
# Rhombuses

What make a shape a rhombus?

* **All sides the same length**
* $4$ sides (because it is a quadrilateral)

### Study some examples

Here are some examples of rhombuses:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b2595517850937f4eeea9e43cda0b00f64f6e3fd)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a8be828e068fab761c6e9eb3208a862dc2aceb7c)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6a9920ad78f6543ada06d39588cc4e55e75da877)

[[☃ explanation 2]]

### Try it yourself

[[☃ graded-group 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The following shapes are rhombuses because they are quadrilaterals with all sides of equal length:  


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d23859995c1e45efa945f510d9c906fb1da6856a)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/36e3e3ad44c8416f2aaf2c8389aaf014973277ee)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b5115f03c8fe40ca8a2331eb01c921ccd369058)

Yes, it is!  

A rhombus is a $\blueD{\text{quadrilateral}}$ with $\greenD{\text{all sides of equal length}}$.

Squares are $\blueD{\text{quadrilaterals}}$.  Squares have $\greenD{\text{all sides of equal length}}$.

So, squares are rhombuses!
options.showPrompt: ÎÏśŝńň'ťț ťțĥȟáàťț ĺľáàśŝťț óòńňéè áà śŝʠúùáàŕřéè?

options.content:
**Which of the following shapes are rhombuses?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
#Squares

What makes a shape a square?

* Sides of equal length
* $4$ right angles
* $4$ sides (because it's a quadrilateral)

### Study some examples

Here are some examples of squares:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/efb7237a501633eb335c44cb62fe0d6ab6126f45)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/43208ccdd2ceb9db1d2576ae0bac4dad60c4f80a)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/41dde39e03feb9811e32de8f05bc7eba98fb33c9)

### Try it yourself

[[☃ graded-group 1]]

[[☃ explanation 2]]

options.explanation:
The following shapes are squares because they are quadrilaterals with $4$ right angles $\underline{\text{and}}$ all sides of equal length:  


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/27d7693f5ac5ea41df1c773cd3f396a3eb26bc81)![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0fafa9ba35d0da8409b449ed240a713701f5f536)

options.content:
**Which of the following shapes are squares?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.explanation:
A rectangle is a quadrilateral with $\blueD{\text{4 right angles}}$.

A rhombus is a quadrilateral with $\greenD{\text{all sides of equal length}}$.


A square is a quadrilateral with $\blueD{\text{4 right angles}}$ and $\greenD{\text{all sides of equal length}}$.

So, a square is a rectangle $\underline{\text{and}}$ a rhombus.  

The solution is to draw a square.

options.content:
**Drag the points to create a shape that is both a rectangle and a rhombus.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

options.explanation:
A quadrilateral is a $\goldD{\text{4-sided polygon}}$.  Is this shape a $\goldD{\text{4-sided polygon}}$? Yes!

A rectangle is a quadrilateral with $\blueD{\text{4 right angles}}$. Does this shape have $\blueD{\text{4 right angles}}$? Yes!

A rhombus is a quadrilateral with $\greenD{\text{all sides of equal length}}$. Does this shape have $\greenD{\text{all sides of equal length}}$? Yes!


A square is a $\goldD{\text{4-sided polygon}}$ with $\blueD{\text{4 right angles}}$ and $\greenD{\text{all sides of equal length}}$.  Is this shape a square?  Yes!

So, the shape is a quadrilateral, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

options.content:
**Which of the following describe this shape?**

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0793d066c44332fb1dd89e4e2dbf1a929291ab5e)
